title: The Needle Remembers

quest_giver.name: Council of Oath and River
quest_giver.affiliation: Protector Arelon Vale, Prior Ansel of the Black Thistle, Guildmother Brynna Coil, and Master Pilot Olan Vetch

description: Stormless noon bares the basalt like a blade, and all Thornspire holds its breath as if the city itself has stepped into a room of mirrors and dared not move. Needle Keep glimmers under a burnished light that looks like rain remembered rather than falling, each green-copper roof a pooled thought, each slit-window a keen eye that does not blink. In the Oath Hall, the iron-thistle chain lies coiled like a sleeping serpent along the sluice veins, its barbed links inked with dwarven chant-marks that promise temper if the song is kept and shattering if it is forgotten. The relic-needle rests beside the Oathstone like a thorn set carefully beside a wound that is ready to be stitched, and above a basin of Glasslake-calm water the reflection-cutting lens hangs in its brass cradle, the hush-silk bindings whispering of the Cathedral that wove them. The tri-fold compact, borne from the Lantern Archive in a traveling case, waits with ink not quite dry, the words humming faintly as if eager to learn the city’s voice. Below, the Low Veyne parts and braids like hands worrying a prayer-script, and on those troubled fingers skulks the reed-thing, no longer a rumor but a man-shaped skein of broken oath-threads, its mouth a slit of living reeds, its eyes wet with borrowed promises it never earned. Kezra Thorneglass must call the rain-chains to song and read them like a map, must hum iron to the dwarves’ marks until chain and sluice remember the river’s spine, must pierce the Oathstone’s missing corner and suture the wound with the relic-needle while the Order intones the founding vows, and must hold steady as the drowned queen’s memory leans close and asks to be fed the promised name. When the mirrored path of the old demon rises in the basin, it must be cut clean and salted dark, the cut anchored by a public oath-chart that any citizen may read and none may hoard. What is bound here will haunt or shelter Thornspire for generations, and the city’s price will be paid in salt, in name, and in the quiet courage to speak the truth even when the water listens. In halls and alleys, in lofts of silk and under-docks of weed, the city waits to learn whether its memory will be a net that saves or a rope that tightens.
objectives: Thread and position the iron-thistle chain through the Needle Keep’s hidden sluice-veins, then tune its links to the living cadence of the rain-chains by matching the dwarven chant-marks until iron, water, and stone hum one note.

Suture the Oathstone’s missing corner with the relic-needle while the Order of the Black Thistle recites the founding vows in measured breath; at the precise verse, feed the drowned queen’s memory the promised name so that hunger gives way to watchfulness.

Raise the reflection-cutting lens above a basin of still, salted water, draw forth the demon’s mirrored path as it tries to ride the city’s shadow, and cut it clean; seal the severed image with dark salt and sign the tri-fold public oath-chart so the cut becomes civic law.

Withstand the reed-thing’s assault as it tries to devour the newborn vow; hold the compact steady, keep the hall’s light unbroken, and bind the final words into the Lantern Archive’s traveling lamp so the city remembers in public flame.

dialogue.speaker: Prior Ansel of the Black Thistle
dialogue.lines: We stand where our first vows were hewn into stubborn stone and then recut when time taught us our first measures were not enough. If our hands are unsteady, let it be from the honest weight of oath and not the tremor of fear, for fear makes a poor scribe and a worse judge. Kezra, the chapter will set its breath to your cadence, because the chain will hear what the city truly means only if a steady voice names each turn of the link. Speak the map that the rain-chains sing, and we will keep the beat with the old thistle-prick upon our tongues that reminds us how truth tastes. When the creature of unraveling steps into our threshold, we shall not meet it with blades, but with sentences that hold, clauses that do not slip, and the final period that rings like a bell in a winter morning.

dialogue.speaker: Brynna Coil
dialogue.lines: If my hands shake, it is the ache of looms that have worked long seasons and not the tremor of cowardice that makes silk snag and tear. The hush-silk wrapped around your lens cradle was woven in a night of fasting and hymn, and its threads have learned to drink screams rather than amplify them, so let us put it to that mercy. I will set my feet to the pedals and sing the moth-hymn under your spoken measures, and you will hear how the chain begins to choose a pitch that matches both hammer and wing. Do not be shy to ask for more breath from me when the water swells, because a good loom does not judge the cloth that passes—only the tension that makes it true. Tonight the city’s cloth must be a shroud for an old lie and a banner for a new promise, and we will hem its edges so no guild can fray it without the whole of Thornspire feeling the rip.

dialogue.speaker: Olan Vetch
dialogue.lines: I have piloted in fog that tasted like regret and in nights so black the stars felt like bits of salt tossed in a bucket, but this is a different channel altogether. In this hall the current runs through words, and the shoals are the places where one lie has been piled on another until a barge grounds in its own profit. If the reed-thing tries for the stair, it will learn that some pilots were born with their feet braced to hold a line while the whole river pulls the other way, and I will hold that line until the skin comes off my palms. I will whistle the forbidden calls that only storm-years hear if the water rises, and let the sound corkscrew up the Needle so that every pilot’s oar in Thornspire turns in time with your breath. Give me a line to hold, Kezra, and I will stake my oar and my name in it, because a name anchored to a good line will pull a city through a flood where coin will only sink and shine to no purpose.

dialogue.speaker: Arelon Vale
dialogue.lines: When this is done, I shall owe debts I cannot count and forgive debts I should never have carried, for a Protector is not a ledger and yet too often I have behaved like one. If we fail, we will do so together and in sight of all who matter, and I will not permit a single back stair for excuses or a private door for blame to hide behind. If we succeed, no one will hawk the story by the ell in the markets, for I will sign this compact to make memory a commons and not a commodity. Kezra, drive the needle when I speak, and I shall speak behind you until my voice runs raw, because it is better for a Protector to bleed words today than for barges to bleed children tomorrow. The city trusted me once to read a river; it must trust us all now to read our own reflection and not flinch at what we see.

dialogue.speaker: The Drowned Queen’s Memory
dialogue.lines: Salt, and a name, little oath-keeper, and do not try to cut a mirror without wetting your hands, for water remembers who has been kind. Feed me what was promised, and I will put a stone inside my hunger so that it grows slow for a generation, and I will watch the children cross by safe shallows when the river forgets itself. Yet do not forget me, for memory starved becomes cruelty, and I have worn cruelty like a crown when the living cease to speak me with respect. I remember cities that tried to buy me with coin rather than names, and their streets now sleep under reed-roots that tickle the ankles of fish, so do not bring me coin, bring me the right syllables at the right time. Bind me to watch and I will watch, bind me to mercy and I will be merciful, but bind me to silence and I will learn to sing in storms where your roofs have no ears.

dialogue.speaker: Kezra Thorneglass
dialogue.lines: Rain-chains, sing the old measures you learned from roofs that have held three sieges and two summers that went too far, and let me read you as a pilot reads a sound in the dark. Iron, remember the dwarves who knocked you awake with hammers and taught you to hum true rather than loud, and lend your certainty to our wavering mortal breath. Stone, hold and be held, for you have carried names both fair and false, and tonight we would stitch a wound in you with a thorn that knows the taste of penance. River, take what is yours and leave what is ours, and let the salt we pour be a boundary, not a boast, and let the cut we make in your reflection be a mercy that keeps both of us from swallowing the other. In this light I lift the mirrored path that would drown us and lay it down in dark salt; in this needle I bind the corner back to the vow; in this chart we write what cannot be hoarded; in this lamp we make a memory that burns without permission slips and that warms without lying.

choices.title: Speak the Promised Name True
choices.text: Kezra kneels at the basin when the verse arrives and does not reach for a stranger’s syllables nor a rival’s debt, but for the small, sharp truth paid long ago in the Mire. The breath-name given in fear is taken up now in courage, shaped carefully so that the drowned queen’s memory hears it as an offering and not a surrender. The hall feels the hush change, not to emptiness but to a fullness like a lung that has finally learned to exhale properly, and the rain-chains’ song settles into a key that seems older than the city. Allies glance at one another and understand that what has been paid cannot be bought back with coin, only honored in its keeping. The reed-thing stiffens at the threshold, as if the threads that made it were suddenly shown the pattern they used to belong to, and for a beat it forgets to move.
choices.outcome: The queen’s memory is gentled; she agrees to watch the city’s fords and gates with soft eyes for a generation, and the river’s sudden cruelties become rare rather than seasonal. Kezra bears a faint pull toward reed and water during starry weather, a reminder-thread that tugs them to the Floodwalk when the lanterns burn low, but it is a guide rather than a chain. Prior Ansel marks the compact with a clause that no guild may abridge, and the Order’s reliquary lantern finally holds its flame without sputter for the first time in months. The reed-thing falters in its devouring and must fight for breath like a liar forced to speak a long truth, giving the company the moments needed to bind the last stanza. The city whispers Kezra’s courage in markets and on towpaths, and though Night Cartographers sniff for leverage, they find none they can price without cutting their own fingers.

choices.title: Borrow a Powerful Name Instead
choices.text: Kezra hesitates at the water’s edge and reaches not for their own promise but for a name carried like a coin in the mouth, a name that owes the city and has never paid. The syllables chosen are weighty, steeped in authority and ledger-ink, and they drop into the basin with the dull splash of something hammered thin. The drowned queen’s memory pauses, curious at the taste, and does not reject it outright, for hunger is pragmatic even when it remembers etiquette. The chain hum stutters for a bar before finding itself again, as if the iron wonders who is binding whom and which hand it serves. Allies exchange glances that carry both hope and worry, and the reed-thing leans forward like a market clerk who has smelled a discount and means to make it expensive.
choices.outcome: The queen accepts the substitute, but the bond is clever rather than tender, and it holds with a lawyer’s knots that will need retying in less than a generation. A quiet geas falls on the powerful name’s bearer to perform three public works the city can point to without argument, and until they are done the river treats that person like a slippery stone. The chain keeps pitch, but it sings more sharply, and some nights the sluice-veins ring like wire in the wind, making children wake with thirsty mouths. The reed-thing snarls and presses hard against the new vow, seeking the loose stitch, and the company must spend breath and sweat to keep the compact steady as a second chorus is spoken. The compact holds and the rewards stand, but a faint rift opens between factions about whether ends justify cunning means, and Kezra will have to mend that seam in future councils.

choices.title: Blend Songs: Dwarf Hammer and Moth Hymn
choices.text: At the tuning, Kezra raises a hand and asks for both beats at once, inviting Dhorik’s hammer-prayer in slow, grounded strokes while Brynna’s pedals answer with a shimmer like moth-wings crossing evening. The rain-chains, long accustomed to roof and storm alone, discover a third rhythm that runs like a bright thread between earth and air. Iron begins to hum not only with strength but with patience, and silk answers not only with quiet but with backbone, and the two find a pitch together that neither held alone. Olan listens and grins like a man who has found a channel where none was charted, and the Protector nods once, as if feeling an aching hinge set true. The reed-thing, woven of broken patterns, twitches as the stronger weave forms in the hall and can no longer find a loose end to worry between its damp fingers.
choices.outcome: The chain seats true, and its vibration softens the hall’s hard corners the way a boat’s keel softens chop when trimmed right, making the work that follows steadier for all hands. Dwarves at the Skygrind Steps hear about it within the week, and a quiet boon flows down the Ember Road in the form of a chant-stone that keeps the sluices in tune through heat and drought alike. The Loom Cathedral’s apprentices take notes and begin to weave service silks that hold oaths without gagging speech, a small miracle that eases future rites. The reed-thing finds no purchase in the tuning and must resort to brute rushing later, losing the advantage it hoped the music would give it. The city remembers the night when crafts met without bristling, and the Hall of Shares cannot price the feeling, which is part of why it lasts.

choices.title: Cut Only the Demon’s Path, Not a Single Secret More
choices.text: When the mirrored current climbs the basin like a snake of light, Kezra aims the Glasslake lens with surgeon’s restraint, refusing the hungry temptation to shave off a rival’s shadow-route or a private shame while the edge is keen. The cut is unadorned, a single patient stroke that respects the danger of reflections and the cost of every added flourish. Salt follows in a black ribbon, poured with the measured care a pilot gives to sounding in a treacherous bend, and the hiss it makes is approval rather than pain. The chart is signed in the traveling lamp’s glow, each letter drawn slowly enough to be legible to a tired dockhand and a proud guildsman alike. Around the hall, people exhale the sort of breath that brings them back to themselves, and even the rain-chains seem relieved to be asked for nothing more than what they were built to give.
choices.outcome: The demon’s routed habit is cut from the city’s shadow as cleanly as a rope parted by a sharp knife, and the severed path curls into the salt and dies without a story left to tell. No one’s private map is lighter, and no one’s secret debt is scissored, and so no one is owed blackmail over tonight’s mercy, which gives the compact a moral timber even the cynical can lean against. The Night Cartographers mutter at the lost opportunity but cannot credibly accuse, and their price for cooperation drops a notch in quiet recognition of a power that chose restraint. The reed-thing lunges, starved of leverage, and is quieted when Kezra binds the last stanza into the lamp, after which it unravels like a wet knot under honest fingers. The Lantern Oath-Chart enters the Archive with a candor that makes it difficult to corrupt, and the city feels lighter not because it forgot, but because it remembered cleanly.

rewards.description: Establishment of the Lantern Oath-Chart as a public trust, granting open access to safe routes and conferring civic authority to the memory that guards them.
River Oath-Reader of Thornspire, a recognized standing across guilds and chapels that allows Kezra to witness contracts and read routes in the city’s name.
Markers from the Riverlight Pilots, the Spindlewrights, and the Order of the Black Thistle—callable favors that will answer whistle, thread, or thorn when rightly invoked.
Quieting of the reed-thing; the canals run safer and trade steadies for a season as fear loosens its grip on the Floodwalk and the Weir Market.
